dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we often talk about climate change, right? But what if I told you there's an even bigger picture we need to consider?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we often talk about climate change, right? But what if I told you there's an even bigger picture we need to consider?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely. I think a lot of people are starting to realize that, um, it's not just about rising temperatures anymore. We're also seeing huge threats to, like, biodiversity, our soil, the air we breathe, our oceans, freshwater systems... it's all connected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely. I think a lot of people are starting to realize that, um, it's not just about rising temperatures anymore. We're also seeing huge threats to, like, biodiversity, our soil, the air we breathe, our oceans, freshwater systems... it's all connected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While few dispute the need to combat climate change, the Earths biodiversity, soil, air, oceans, and freshwater systems are also increasingly threatened. Together, these natural systems interact with the climate and determine the environmental conditions for the entire planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And these natural systems, they interact with the climate, they determine the conditions for our entire planet. And if those conditions keep getting worse, we're talking about millions of lives and livelihoods at risk, especially in the Global South.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And these natural systems, they interact with the climate, they determine the conditions for our entire planet. And if those conditions keep getting worse, we're talking about millions of lives and livelihoods at risk, especially in the Global South.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should those conditions continue deteriorating, the lives and livelihoods of millions of people, especially in the Global South, will be at risk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, uh, pretty stark when you think about it. For the first time ever, policymakers and scientists are really having to look at how much human activity is, like, threatening the stable conditions that have allowed societies to flourish for the last ten thousand years. We're at a dangerous tipping point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, uh, pretty stark when you think about it. For the first time ever, policymakers and scientists are really having to look at how much human activity is, like, threatening the stable conditions that have allowed societies to flourish for the last ten thousand years. We're at a dangerous tipping point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is why, for the first time in history, policymakers and the science community must consider the extent to which man-made forces are threatening the benign conditions that have allowed societies to flourish over the last 10,000 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A tipping point where the Earth's natural systems might stop *absorbing* our harmful effects and start *intensifying* them. And what's really sobering is, like, even phasing out fossil fuels, which is crucial, isn't going to be enough on its own.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A tipping point where the Earth's natural systems might stop absorbing our harmful effects and start intensifying them. And what's really sobering is, like, even phasing out fossil fuels, which is crucial, isn't going to be enough on its own.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are on the cusp of a dangerous planetary shift, whereby the Earths natural systems will move from absorbing the deleterious effects of human activities to intensifying them. ... Worse, we can already say with certainty that phasing out fossil fuels, while necessary, will not be enough to meet the Paris agreements target of keeping global warming well below 2°C relative to pre-industrial levels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. The Paris Agreement targets, while vital, won't be met if we don't also safeguard the health of *all* our natural systems – from polar regions to rainforests to oceans. We need, um, shared targets for the entire Earth system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. The Paris Agreement targets, while vital, won't be met if we don't also safeguard the health of all our natural systems - from polar regions to rainforests to oceans. We need, um, shared targets for the entire Earth system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Worse, we can already say with certainty that phasing out fossil fuels, while necessary, will not be enough to meet the Paris agreements target of keeping global warming well below 2°C relative to pre-industrial levels. We also will need to safeguard the health and functionality of natural systems, from polar regions and forests to grasslands and marine environments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it's interesting because companies and cities are actually starting to get it. I mean, after those devastating fires in the Amazon, you had like, 230 institutional investors, with trillions in assets, calling for anti-deforestation measures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's interesting because companies and cities are actually starting to get it. I mean, after those devastating fires in the Amazon, you had like, two hundred thirty institutional investors, with trillions in assets, calling for anti-deforestation measures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, in the wake of this years devastating fires in the Amazon basin, 230 institutional investors, representing $16.2 trillion in assets under management, called on companies with supply chains connected to these vulnerable ecosystems to implement new anti-deforestation measures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's huge! But the problem is, while Paris has these quantitative climate targets, we're really lacking specific international targets for, um, all these other global commons. There's just not enough mechanism to translate those benchmarks into actionable standards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's huge! But the problem is, while Paris has these quantitative climate targets, we're really lacking specific international targets for, um, all these other global commons. There's just not enough mechanism to translate those benchmarks into actionable standards.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, while the Paris agreement establishes quantitative science-based targets for tackling climate change, specific international targets for preserving the rest of the global commons are scarce, and there are very few mechanisms for translating such benchmarks into meaningful standards for different countries, companies, and cities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is why this new initiative is so important, right? The first Earth Commission.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is why this new initiative is so important, right? The first Earth Commission.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, the Earth Commission! They're basically going to define science-based targets for maintaining a stable and resilient planet. It's a big deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the Earth Commission! They're basically going to define science-based targets for maintaining a stable and resilient planet. It's a big deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To make up for this shortfall, we are co-chairing the first Earth Commission, which will define science-based targets for maintaining a stable and resilient planet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just a few people. We're talking about 20 internationally recognized scientists from around the world, supported by some major research organizations. They're part of a broader coalition called the Global Commons Alliance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just a few people. We're talking about twenty internationally recognized scientists from around the world, supported by some major research organizations. They're part of a broader coalition called the Global Commons Alliance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the Earth Commission brings together some 20 internationally recognized natural and social scientists from around the world. ... These experts who held their first meeting near Washington, DC in November will form one element of a broader coalition of the willing comprising nongovernmental organizations, businesses, and governments, organized by the Global Commons Alliance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Their work will provide the evidence needed for, um, another coalition member, the Science Based Targets Network, or SBTN, to set really specific, achievable goals for companies and, eventually, cities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their work will provide the evidence needed for, um, another coalition member, the Science Based Targets Network, or S B T N, to set really specific, achievable goals for companies and, eventually, cities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The commissions work will provide the evidence needed to enable another coalition member, the Science Based Targets Network, to carry out its work. The SBTN, which comprises leading environmental institutions and NGOs, will set specific, achievable goals for companies and eventually cities, helping them to reduce their environmental impact and start to restore natural systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The goal is to make these objectives the new standard practice for all businesses and cities by 2025. That's, like, super ambitious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The goal is to make these objectives the new standard practice for all businesses and cities by twenty twenty five. That's, like, super ambitious.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The goal is to make adoption of such objectives the new standard practice for all businesses and cities by 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is! And they also want to foster a mass mobilization of, um, 100 million "planetary stewards" around the world to push for climate action at all levels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! And they also want to foster a mass mobilization of, um, one hundred million "planetary stewards" around the world to push for climate action at all levels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Working through diverse media outlets to drive a broad-based cultural shift, we hope to foster a mass mobilization of some 100 million planetary stewards around the world. Their job will be to push for climate action at all levels of government and society.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, turning this impending crisis of the global commons into, hopefully, a huge opportunity for us all. It's a truly transformative undertaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, turning this impending crisis of the global commons into, hopefully, a huge opportunity for us all. It's a truly transformative undertaking.
